dialog.name: symbol_type
dialog.whatsthis:
Specifies symbol type for the current symbol.

Cell - Cell symbols represent the primitive cells (transistors, resistors, diodes, and so on) used to design integrated circuits. The pins on Cell symbols are named for identification in netlists.

Block - Block symbols are used to build a hierarchical design. A Block symbol represents a schematic or HDL module at the next-lower level of the hierarchy. Bus pins are permitted on Block symbols.

Graphic - Graphic symbols add information that is not part of the circuitry. Graphic symbols are typically used for tables and notes. No pins are associated with Graphic symbols, and they are never included in the hierarchy or netlists.

Master - Master symbols are used for title blocks, logos, revision blocks, and other standardized graphic symbols. You can add text to a Master symbol to display the company name, address, project description, date, and so on.

dialog.name: object_properties
dialog.whatsthis: Lists the current symbol and the pins that are selected in the Symbol Editor window. Click Symbol Attributes or a pin name in the list to show the available attributes in the right-hand table.

Limits the attributes displayed in the table below it. Type a string (wildcards are supported) that includes the characters you want to include and click Go. To recover the original list, erase the string in the edit box and click Go.

Lists the available attributes for the symbol or pin selected in the left-hand Object List. The attributes are listed in alphabetical order. To specify an attribute value, double-click the Value cell, enter the new value, and click Apply.

Controls the pin name position relative to the selected pin.

Left - Displays the pin name to the left of the pin.

Top - Displays the pin name above the pin.

Right - Displays the pin name to the right of the pin.

Bottom - Displays the pin name below the pin.

Vertical - Displays the pin name as vertical text.

Offset - Specifies the distance of the pin name from the pin. Type an offset value in this edit box.
Resets the selected attribute to its original value.
Applies the attribute settings in this dialog box.
dialog.description: Indicates the bounding box or the area for a given UGROUP. Given in number of rows and columns. Convention: BBOX= H,W
Obsolete. Do not use.
Tells Precision RTL Synthesis that the module should not be compiled or optimized. Only the interface need be defined for synthesis.
Attach to a DELAY element to set a coarse delay with CDEL delay parameters.
Attach to a block, to specify a name for the device component that is created when the block is mapped. Convention: COMP(PLC)=comp_name
Attach to a DCS element to set the mode.
Specifies the delay type on the DELAY element.
The differential current-source type driver has programmable output current in each mode of operation.
Attach to input or output buffers (such as IB or OB) to provide differential termination.
Instructs map to pack a DIN/DOUT register into PIO/IOLOGIC sites. Convention: DIN= signal_name
Tells Precision RTL Synthesis to pass the module through synthesis without optimizing or unmapping.
Instructs map to pack a DIN/DOUT register into PIO/IOLOGIC sites. Convention: DOUT= signal_name
Obsolete. Use Spreadsheet View to apply the TO keyword in the BLOCK, MAXDELAY, and MULTICYCLE constraints instead.
Attach to a DELAY element to set a fine delay with FDEL delay parameters.
Enables or disables the global set/reset for registered elements such as registers, PLLs, and memories.
Group components that are to be instantiated multiple times. Convention: HGROUP= identifier
Tells Precision RTL Synthesis to maintain the hierarchy of the module.
Indicates the physical location of the northwest corner of an HGROUP or UGROUP assignment. Convention: HULOC = row#col#
Indicates the northwest corner of a region for a given HGROUP or UGROUP definition. Convention: HURLOC = row#col#
Sets the on-chip programmable output impedance.
Attach to output and bidirectional buffers to connect to ground.
Attach to output and bidirectional buffers to connect to high.
INBUF is a global setting. All unused input buffers are disabled when INBUF is OFF to save power.
Attach to an output buffer to modify loading on outputs from the default 50 pF for timing analysis. Convention: LOAD= xx.xx
Specifies a site location for the component that is created when this block is mapped. Convention: LOC= site_name
Tells Precision RTL Synthesis that an instance should not be optimized or changed.
Prevents re-timing on the hierarchy of the instance. Convention: NORETIME= string
Attach to input combinations to reduce the common mode range.
Indicates the area of a region. Convention: RBBOX = H,W
Allows you to choose this internal reference circuit or an external one.
Indicates the region to which a given HGROUP or UGROUP belongs. Convention: REGION = identifier
Obsolete. Do not use.
Attach to an output buffer or pad to specify the relative speed (slew rate) of the output driver, with 1 indicating the slowest and 100 the fastest.
Tells Synplify Pro to treat the module as a black box during synthesis.
Tells Synplify Pro how to control the amount of hierarchical transformation that occurs across boundaries on module or component instances during optimization.
Tells Synplify Pro whether or not to generate the hierarchy in the EDIF output when assigned to the top-level module of your design. The default (true) is to allow hierarchy generation.
Tells Synplify Pro to treat the ports of a design unit as individual signals (scalars), not as buses (arrays) in the EDIF file.
Tells Synplify Pro whether or not to remove instances that have outputs that are not driven.
This attribute determines the on-chip parallel input and output termination.
This attribute determines the on-chip parallel input and output termination.
This attribute sets the on-chip input parallel termination to VTT.
Universal grouping construct.Convention:UGROUP = identifier
Attached to input buffer elements (e.g., IB), assigning value types allows you to enable a common mode voltage, that is, choose between common mode termination or VTT termination.

dialog.name: options
dialog.whatsthis: Controls whether the Grid is displayed. The grid appears as dots, with one dot at every grid intersection. Every tenth grid point is larger. As you zoom out and the grid points get closer, some grid dots might not be displayed.
There are two line weights for drawing lines and rectangles. Select this option to use the heavier weight in your drawing. Wide lines have the same weight as buses on schematics.
Specifies the default symbol type. The selected type will be the default symbol created every time you start the Symbol Editor.
